text: [music playing]

HOLLY FIRFER: In a land that is
timeless, in a space that seems

endless, a natural
wonder is full of life
in a secluded part of Kenya.

RICHARD PYE: Well,
the Mara, I think is--

I would say it's one
of the jewels of Safari

because you can
come to this place

and in a very,
very short period,

in a very short
distance, you can

see what would take a lot longer
to do in a much larger area
elsewhere.

HOLLY FIRFER: On
this Safari, you
do it all in the lap of luxury.

With just seven opulent tents
at the Mara Plains Camp,

no detail has been missed in
this all inclusive adventure.

Relax in your room and
listen to the hippos
that call from the river below.

Sit back and watch the
giraffes, gazelles, zebras,
baboons wander by.

Enjoy five-star open air dining
from some of Kenya's top chefs.

And when you're ready
to begin your journey

over the 30,000 natural acres,
your private guide awaits.

There are five small caps
here on about 30,000 acres

of conservancy land, and
only jeeps from those camps

are allowed on this
property, which is why game
drives here are so private.

RICHARD PYE: The more exclusive
the camp, the more exclusive

the car, the most
exclusive the experience.

And you can sit, like
I was this morning,
with a cheetah hunting.

And I was the only
vehicle there.
You can't get that many places.

HOLLY FIRFER: For those who
want a more immersive safari

on the conservancy land, create
your own adventure on horseback

without having to
do any of the work.

MARTIN DODWELL: We
have the breeches,

jumpers, the boots,
we have helmets,
troxel helmets, gloves.

If you forget your
socks, we'll have
water with us, cold drinks.
We got everything.

Well, it's East Africa,
which, it's go to a remoteness
still about it.
It's got an innocence about it.
It's just nature at its best.
You're on a horse.

All horse riders know
that to be on a horse

is one thing, but to look out
and to have an endless vista.

And then if you
have a herd of Toby

or wildebeest come past
you, you can actually

go and join them, and
just get in the excitement
of the whole thing.

RICHARD PYE: When you're in
any beautiful place like this,

and you're looking around
and seeing beautiful things

and hearing beautiful
things and eating,

and you're just--
you're just filling
all your senses with goodness.
And that's good soul food.

So when you're lying
in bed at night,

and you're listening to lions
roaring and hyenas and a zebra,

and it-- it just-- it really is
where we came from as humans.
This is our route.

HOLLY FIRFER: In the
outskirts of Nairobi,

in the shadows of sunrise, comes
a once in a lifetime encounter.

As guests awaken, these gentle
giants beckon at Giraffe Manor,

a 1930s hunting
lodge transformed

into a 10-room bespoke
all inclusive hotel

that sits on a 140-acre
sanctuary aimed at protecting
a threatened species.

MICKEY CARR-HARTLEY: They know
through a bit like Pavlov's
dog, with habituation.

They know that first thing
in the morning as the sun

comes out, the guests come out,
there's a little bit of noise,

and they walk up to the
house as the sun is rising

and basically stick their
heads through the windows

of the manor in
the breakfast rooms
and have breakfast with you.

The Giraffe Manor
experience is not replicated
anywhere in the world.
It is a Nairobi city icon.

It is one of those amazing
bucket list type things

that people really,
really want to do,

and often save up for years
to come and experience.

And that's why we try and
make it as special for each
and every guest as we can.

You know, Kenya is
this amazing country.

You know, where
safari came from,
the word safari means journey.
It's a Swahili word from Kenya.

It is the icon of
African Safari.

HOLLY FIRFER: Holly
Firfer, CNN, Kenya.
